talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: If a child is born to a couple as a result of in-vitro fertilisation treatment, and the couple subsequently separates, is the (a) non-custodial parent liable to pay child support and (b) custodial parent required to seek to obtain that child support as a condition of accessing social security if the couple has been (i) married, (ii) in a defacto heterosexual relationship and (iii) in a same sex relationship.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Community Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (a) Generally, yes.

(b) (i) Applicants for Family Tax Benefit Part A cannot receive more than the base rate unless they take `reasonable action' to obtain child support. Where a couple separates the resident parent will be required to take action to obtain child support.
(ii) Under Family Assistance Law, defacto couples are treated in the same manner as legally married couples.

(iii) Same sex couples who separate following an artificial conception procedure are generally not required to take action to obtain child support. This is because, generally, in the case of same sex couples, neither the ex-partner nor the donor is a parent of the child for the purposes of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) What is the average period for approval of applications from newly married Australian citizens and permanent residents wishing to sponsor their spouse to come to Australia from the time the application is made to the approval time.

(2) What is the average time for approval of applications for spouses coming from (a) Great Britain, (b) Ireland, (c) Western Europe, (d) Croatia, (e) Hungary, (f) Romania, (g) Baltic States, (h) Russian Federation, (i) Slovakia, (j) Czech Republic, (k) Slovenia, (l) Poland, (m) Turkey, (o) Israel, (q) Jordan, (r) Syria, (s) Egypt, (t) Iran, (u) Afghanistan, (v) Pakistan, (w) India, (x) Sri Lanka, (y) China, (z) Japan, (aa) Philippines, (ab) South Korea, (ac) Thailand, (ad) Malaysia, (ae) Hong Kong, (af) Singapore, (ag) Indonesia, (ah) Fiji, (ai) Papua New Guinea, (aj) Samoa, (ak) Vanuatu, (al) USA, (am) Canada, (an) Latin America, (ao) Sudan, (ap) Ethiopia, (aq) Kenya, (ar) Zimbabwe, (as) South Africa, (at) Ghana, (au) Nigeria and (av) Mauritius.
(3) Are there unjustifiable delays in the processing of applications, especially from certain countries; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Average periods to approval are normally measured as median processing times to visa grant. For subclass 309 Spouse (Provisional) visas, the median time to visa grant at the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs' (DIMA) overseas posts is 28 weeks. This is based on 5118 cases approved during the period 1 March 2000 to 31 August 2000.

(2) The average time for approval of applications for spouses `coming from' each of the countries listed, is based on the median processing time for the responsible post where a DIMA post is located in the country mentioned. In some cases, figures for several posts have been aggregated, for example, Western Europe comprises Berlin, Paris, Rome, The Hague and Vienna.
The table below shows the median time from lodgement to approval for all cases lodged in the six month period from 1 March 2000 to 31 August 2000 for the selected countries.

In some cases the DIMA post is responsible for processing cases from more than one country and this has been indicated by brackets. Figures for Pakistan and Afghanistan are based on cases recorded for the country of birth of the applicant, as applications from Afghanistan are mainly processed in Islamabad.
(3) Processing times can vary among countries for a range of reasons including:
- Difficulties in verifying claims where reliable documentation is not available
- Delays associated with health concerns that may arise (eg Tuberculosis, HIV)
- Difficulties in obtaining penal certificates
- Difficulty of travel and communications
- Lack of a processing post in the country of origin requiring travel by officers of a nearby post in order to undertake interviews or site visits
- Staff absences or illness at a post
- Other processing workloads that have been given priority for example, temporary entry surges
- Special circumstances such as civil unrest or natural disasters.
Given these factors, processing times for posts are considered to be justifiable but can be improved. Strategies to achieve improvements continue to be developed and implemented.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Sport and Tourism, upon notice, on 9 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) What is the expected increase in international tourism to Australia over the next ten years.
(2) Has her department provided advice on the capacity of Sydney Airport to cope with the projected increase; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss Jackie Kelly
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) International visitor arrivals to Australia are expected to increase at an average annual rate of 7.3 per cent, growing from 4,459,500 in 1999 to reach 8,409,000 in 2008.
(2) Yes. The advice is confidential as part of the Government's deliberations on this issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

(2) Does this statement reflect Government policy; if so, what type of opt-out arrangements is the Government planning to introduce for the Medicare system.
(3) Has the Government considered exempting private insurance holders fromthe Medicare levy; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
